Uh so when it comes to world partition,
as I mentioned before, there's there's a
metric ton of different entities uh in
the game that you just don't see. And we
divided the world up into multiple
streaming volumes for anyone wondering
the different colors. We would take the
very center is highly divided as you can
see here. That's where all of the game
logic is. And we're very aggressive with
turning on and off interactive systems.
Like if the fishing pond is off in the
distance, it's inert. when you get close
by, then it starts spawning the fish and
then just by the time you get there and

aggressive with removing anything that's
uh on tick and uh this I I would highly

like
there there's so many things that you're
able to get away with on like PS4, PS5
where like you just have raw horsepower,
but if you want to still pull off a lot
of stuff, the Switch like you start
looking into occlusion queries and all

milliseconds. Um, one other add-on I
highly recommended for people is a mesh
pack which automatically handles when
you cook your project, uh, anything that
is can that can be mass instance like
inst static meshes, it will just do
it'll analyze the whole world and group
and batch them for you. That that saved
us so much time. Uh, when it comes to
virtual textures for handling memory,
they're really handy, but they're good
and bad. like the second you use virtual
textures on your materials, your
material instruction count goes up by
like 100 instructions. Um, and uh, it's
it has a lot of extra shader cost. And
then the other thing to also keep an eye
on is uh, if you're ever going to do
profiling and you see body setup in your
profiler and it's like really big, that
means you have a lot of physics data
that's on in the world that there's no
reason it should be on or that big.
Yeah.
So, uh, LDS, let's see here. We're not
using nanite. So
when you're doing world partition
streaming, meshes can only go down or
stay in memory at the lowest LOD you
have for it. So if you forget to set up
an asset and it's got like 20,000
triangles as its lowest LOD, you're
probably sitting there with like five,
six megs just sitting there in memory
that cannot stream out. It's the same
logic with uh textures. The lowest map
is going to be the the last thing that
sits there in memory if you're not using
virtual textures.
Uh, let's see here.
Virtual textures work best on unique
assets. So, something that doesn't get
reused a lot in the world, it's easier
to stream it out. But my recommendation
to anyone is if you have assets that
constantly reuse the same textures, uh,
you know, like they repeat a lot in the
world, you're better off just working
with a texture atlas, um, and just
reserve that memory ahead of time. Like
this thing is always going to be in
memory. it's never going to stream out.
Um,
and for anyone that does VFX, virtual
textures are absolutely useless. Do not
put them in VFX. The second you start
shifting around UVs in your shaders, it
invalidates the uh, virtual texture um,
atlases and it has to recalculate them.
